datosGenerales.descripcion:
Around 5,000 junior players from the five continents will participate in the Donosti Cup International Junior Players Tournament on July 1-7.

Over 800 teams were registered last year placing the Donostia Cup tournament on the top of the contests that are held in the State.

Gipuzkoa's and international referees will make comply with the rules in the matches to be played at 50 different stadiums: Anoeta mini-stadium, Matigoxotegi, Berio, Herrera, Jasonebaso, Martutene, Zubieta, San Ignacio, Hernani, Urnieta, Fanderia...

Besides, a plasma display panel will screen live broadcast of the tournament results alternating with tournament images, video clips, football videos, and so on.

datosContacto.direccion: Mini estadio de Anoeta, Matigoxotegi, Berio, Herrera, Jasonebaso, Martutene, Zubieta, San Ignacio, Hernani, Urnieta y Fanderia.

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Hernani; Lasarte-Oria; Donostia / San Sebastián; Urnieta
localizacion.nombreLocalidad: Hernani; Lasarte; Donostia / San Sebastián; Urnieta

datosGenerales.nombre: Guide tour: Agorregi Foundry and Mills
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Dating back to the 18th century, Agorregi is situated in the Pagoeta Natural Park. The ironworks and mill complex comprise the Agorregi foundry and four mills, which are completely restored. Besides, the infrastructure is made up of reservoirs, dams and channels.

 

They organise guided tours to explain the exploitation of hydraulic energy in the 18th century iron making process as well as in milling.

Visitors can admire the running of the foundry and two of the mills'. As for the foundry, visitors can see how reservoirs collect water, channels, water depots and so on. Here we will find smelting furnaces, bellows and the mallet to hammer and shape the iron.

 



Running two of the four mills visitors will be able to admire the exploitation of water for grain grinding. The upper mill is equipped with only one wheel, whereas the inferior mill has two pairs, the first pair for the grain grinding and the second pair for the corn.

 

 Guided tours start at 11:30am.  For more information call:
943 835 389 / iturraran@gipuzkoanatura.eus

datosGenerales.nombre: The Disembarkation of Juan Sebastián Elcano
datosGenerales.descripcion:
On September 6, 1522, Juan Sebastián Elcano sailed into Sanlúcar de Barrameda (Cádiz) following the first voyage around the world by ship. He arrived starving, barefoot and clothed in rags together with 17 of the 200 sailors who 1,124 days before embarked in Seville at the service of Magallanes.

 

On September 6, Getaria inhabitants will pay homage once again to their distinguished son by an accurate performance of the landing. Every four years since 1922 the small port gets flooded with people who wait to see the dirty-looking Elcano disembarking from the Nao Victoria along with 17 sailors. All of them carry candles in their hands and walk to the church to give thanks to the Virgin for being back home.

 

After getting dressed up, they present before the emperor Carlos I, who, in those times, recognised the heroic deed conceding him a coat of arms and those present listen to an ode to Elcano sung by the inhabitants. The historic performance takes place every four years within the San Salvador festivities' planning. The day finishes with a medieval fair, which, from the morning gives the place some atmosphere to the deed and prepares the mood to welcome Juan Sebastián Elcano in the afternoon.

The main protagonist of the most important day of Laudio/Llodio festivities is the black pudding.

 

During the day, the popular sausage can be found at bars, "txokos" (premises where friends gather), houses and on the streets in the shape of "pintxos", sandwiches, grilled and fried black puddings, and so on.

 

The tradition goes back over 400 years, when young bulls were sacrificed to eat them on Sunday at the guild. Every year about 10,000 kg of black puddings are eaten on these dates. Drinks in demijohns, iced white wine with water, cognac, sugar and lemon accompany the sausages.

 

To put an end to the gastronomic day, many events will delight inhabitants, such as a handball modality match...

Magic will flood the streets of Vitoria-Gasteiz during the week-long celebration of the new edition of the International Magic Festival, Magialdia..

 

Every year, some of the most prestigious magicians in the world descend on Vitoria-Gasteiz to wow audiences with their spectacular shows. As is now customary, magic shows will be performed in various schools around the city, and in unusual locations such as at tram stops and in Vitoria-Gasteiz's shop windows.

 

There will be children's workshops in the Plaza Artium and magic tours around the old town.

Melodies from yesteryear will fill the Church of San Pedro Apóstol and Santa María Cathedral in Vitoria-Gasteiz throughout Álava Ancient Music Week.

 

This event was held for the first time in 1982 and attracts world-renowned musicians year after year. Over the course of the week, violoncellos, vihuelas, violins and masterful singers, to name but a few of the attractions on offer, will delight lovers of this type of music.

galeria.titulo: Semana de Música Antigua de Álava

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In 1813, during the Spanish War of Independence, the city of San Sebastián suffered a terrible fire. It was August 31st.

Only one street remained standing, today known as 31st August Street. Every year San Sebastián commemorates this tragic event. Like in past editions, the city will offer a wide range of activities for everyone. On August 31st the main celebration takes place at night. At 9.30pm the lights of the city are switched off and candles are lighted in the balconies and on the streets. Txistularis perform the hymn of the city with their txistus or Basque flutes and then they parade from the church of San Vicente to the church of Santa Maria carrying torches, rifles and trumpets.

Once lights are turned on and the route finished, around 10pm trikitixa players will walk the streets of the Old Town and will liven up the festive atmosphere of the special day.

The Mercado de Antaño (historic market) places the town of Artziniega and its historic buildings into a time machine to recreate a mediaeval market, where the customs and trades of centuries gone by fill its streets for the public to enjoy.

 

This event harks back to Artziniega's role as a centre where overseas trade met inland commerce. Visitors to the Mercado de Antaño will be surprised to see the inhabitants of the town transformed into performers, clerics, craftsmen, inquisitors, pilgrims, maidens, beggars and jesters to liven up its streets, packed for one day with craft products.

The sound of folk music will flood the streets of Getxo during three days. Getxo Folk BBK takes on this new edition between the 13th and 17th of September, and will bring another diverse program of activities.

 

The concerts will take place in the Muxikebarri hall.

The Hermitage of La Antigua in Zumarraga -also known as "the cathedral of the hermitages"- holds a new edition of the Ancient Music Festival.

 

A varied high-quality programme has been set up on the occasion including concerts on every Saturday of September.

galeria.titulo: La Antigua Hermitage - Santa María de Zumarraga

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Basque Festivities are being held on the coastal town of Zarautz since 1924.

That year these festivities were originated aiming to extend tourists' holidays in Zarautz. Since then, from September the 1st to the 9th Zarautz has turned into a municipality where the Basque traditional aspects are the main characters.

Over the week popular lunches are at attendees' disposal, as well as music on the streets, trikitixa contest (two-row Basque diatonic button accordion), dance shows and recitals by bertsolaris (singers of bertso, a musical verse in Basque tradition). All of them scattered over the town.

September the 9th is the most popular day of "Euskal Jaiak", when all the visitors and the neighbours approach Zarautz and flood into the streets dressed in the typical Basque clothes. In the morning festive atmosphere fills the streets where there won't be missing the rhythms of "txistularis" (Basque flute players), "trikitilaris" (players of the Trikikitxa) and dulzaineros (players of dulzaina, a double reed instrument in the oboe family).

Next, it will be the turn of a series of sports activities -Basque pelota games, exhibitions on rural sports-, performances by "bertsolaris"... In the afternoon the popular open-air dance is celebrated in Iñurritza, where festive atmosphere and music will prevail.

In early September, Ordizia celebrates its "Euskal Jaiak" (Basque Festival). During these days you can enjoy activities such as concerts, Basque rural sports, cooking workshops and gastronomic competitions. The most important day of the festival is Wednesday, as a special market is held this day. In the morning there will be a cheese competition, livestock, fruit and vegetables, Basque chickens and a perretxikos mushroom exhibition. A particular highlight is the Latxa goat's cheese competition. Once the winning cheese has been named, the now traditional enchantment is held. In the afternoon the festivities continue on the streets of Goierri; Basque pelota matches between professionals are held on the Beti-Alai fronton court and Joxe Migel Barandiaran Square holds the aizkolaritza wood-chopping championship.

A new edition of the Zegama-Aizkorri alpine marathon will be staged in May, with points counting towards the Golden Trail World Series.

The competitors must complete a demanding run stretching just over 42 kilometres, which begins in Zegama and passes over the Aizkorri mountain range.The marathon includes four of the highest mountain peaks in the Basque Country.

This year it will be held the 37 edition of Habaneras Festival and Sailors' Songs from Getxo. As every year and for three days, melodies related to the sea world will be sung in the town of Bizkaia.

 

Three bands are about to participate in the festival: XARXA,  MESTRE D’AIXA and LIUBA MARIA HEVIA

galeria.titulo: XXXIII Habaneras Festival and Sailors' Songs

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In September Bermeo celebrates Andra Mari festivities, patron saint's day of the fishing village. Within these festivals Día del Arrantzale (Fisherman's Day) is held. That is the most important day regarding these local festivals and inhabitants of Bermeo flood the streets to enjoy the good atmosphere dressed in the typical fishermen clothes.

The festive day offers activities for all tastes. Cycling test for amateurs is one of the most highlighted events among the proposals, as well as "talo" (typical Basque food that is cooked with corn flour and water) contest, mass honouring fishermen, street entertainment with brass bands and fanfares, disco party. Andra Mari festivities are held from September the 1st to the 16th. Día del Arrantzale takes place on September the 9th.

Güeñes celebrates its traditional paper dress contest where lots of different fashion designs made of paper have been exhibited since the 1960s.

The Soineko association organises this event. Participants must tailor their designs exclusively with paper, including accessories. Anyone is able to participate in the competition, divided in two categories: adults and children (up to 14 yrs.). The jury will take into account the following aspects: dressmaking, handmade work, originality and design.

Zumaia celebrates on Sept. 14 the Octopus's Day. Tasting, exhibitions and gastronomic contests are some of the many activities scheduled for that day. The gastronomic contest takes place from 10.30am to 1.30pm.

Participants must prepare their dishes using octopus as main ingredient. Octopus can be cooked in the traditional way -with potatoes- or following more innovative recipes. Thus, every year all recipes are collected, since the event aims to promote the octopus as ingredient for cooking and the modern cuisine in general.

In the course of the centuries the octopus has gained a symbolic importance for Zumaia. This celebration tries to provide the town with a day in which citizens and visitors have the chance to enjoy and praise this cephalopod's characteristics.

We cannot either overlook the fact that the octopus plays an important role in gastronomy, so that it is essential to offer this delicious product to anyone visiting the town.

Once again, Tolosa becomes the meeting point for thousands of beer-lovers.

 

The town of Gipuzkoa will be holding the Beer Fair where different types of worldwide beer will be available: larger, wheat beer, ales, stout, no alcohol beer...

Elorrio will celebrate the following October 2nd its peculiar festivity known as Errebombillos.

The elorriotarras -Elorrio inhabitants- call so the military march that takes place every year in their town. Some believe its origin dates back to the 16th century, when the elorriotarras came back home after the Lepanto Battle and expressed their joy through the town's streets. However, it is probable that this tradition be actually connected with the former armed bands that used to exist in Basque towns.

The party begins at 5am, when the youngsters go all over the town and shoot to the air in places the tradition determines. In the afternoon, the youngsters go around the town again, but this time, if the weather is good, they march in procession with the Virgen del Rosario Virgin. Finally, no matter the weather conditions are, the errebombillos dance at the town's square.

There will be room for more activities such as open-air dances or lamb tastings.

Every first Saturday from June to December inclusive, Gernika-Lumo houses a special monographic fair. This way, Beans Day is held in style on November's first Monday in Gernika. The fair runs the whole morning. As usual, about 30 stands will be settled to offer visitors many locally grown products: fruit, vegetables, cheese, bread and so on. Gernika's beans deserve a special mention, as they will be the main protagonists on that day and have made the town famous.

 

They will be testable in the popular bean meal. The fair finishes with an exhibition of herri-kirolak (Basque rural sports) and activities for the little ones games, bouncy castles. In short, this is a fair that will delight those who enjoy good food.

datosGenerales.nombre: First and last Mondays of October in Gernika-Lumo
datosGenerales.descripcion:
October is a special month in Gernika-Lumo. Numerous fairs of different nature fill the streets of this town of Bizkaia, although, without doubt, the most important events are the fairs held on the first and the last Mondays of October. Cod Day is held on the first Saturday. The inhabitants will have the chance to taste the fish accompanied by Rioja Alavesa wine. Fruit and vegetable fair, exhibition and sale of Basque handicrafts, rural sports exhibition and games for the children complete the day programme.

 

On October 6th and 7th the Basque Contest of Pyrenean breed cow is scheduled to take place. A wide range of activities are included in the programme, and those who approach Gernika-Lumo, will have the possibility to enjoy exhibitions of cattle equipment, cider stalls, txakoli wine and cheese, livestock contest, auctions, rural world exhibitions, and so on. On Monday, cattle raising equipment will be on display together with performances by "bertsolaris" (Basque verse singers). Throughout the day, the winning animals will be selected and prizes awarded.

 

Last Monday

Without doubt, the most important fair is the one held the last Monday of October. That day, about 900 stalls of different types occupy the streets. Fruit, vegetables, flowers, cheese, txakoli wine and honey contests and exhibitions are some of the attractions, as well as cider, bread, sweets, rosquillas (type of doughnuts) and label quality products.

 

Likewise, those who attend the fair will have the possibility to examine how Basque artisan products are made, and the way bertsolaris and street bands complete the day. Jai alai matches, bat games and a variety of Basque pelota game are included in the programme. The good atmosphere and the fiesta are the undisputed characters of the day.

galeria.titulo: Thousands of people approach Gernika the last Monday in October

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Alava pinto bean fair will be celebrated in Pobes, on the second Sunday of October.

 

This delicious legume is the main attraction of the fair, which attracts thousands of people each year. The event kicks off with the display and sale of Alava pinto bean. A craft and typical local produce fair is also organized. The programme finishes off with photographic exhibitions, displays of herri-kirolak (Basque rural sports) and the presentation of the Alava Pinto Bean of Honour prize.

 

As usually happens in this kind of event, attendees will have the chance to sample the produce that the fair centres on: the pinto bean.

Once again, the Igartubeiti Farmhouse Museum will celebrate a special Cider Week.

 

The vast programme of activities includes demonstrations of apple pressing and kirikoketa, a cider or apple recipe contest, an apple exhibition and a photography competition.

datosGenerales.nombre: Farming, handicrafts and cattle fair in Sondika
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Sondika fair takes place every November's second Sunday. The exposition is an accurate image of our best products. Visitors will find a wide offer of food at the agricultural stands and they will have the chance to taste two of the most popular products in the Basque Country: Idiazabal cheese and txakoli wine with Bizkaiko Txakolina protected designation of origin.

Likewise, an interesting cattle exhibition will bring together sheep, cows, horses, poultry and donkeys and visitors will find many objects for purchase at the fair. Another important fair attraction lies in the wide range of parallel activities scheduled for that day.

The little ones will enjoy "herri kirolak" (Basque rural sports) exhibition on the Ikurriña Square and will have the chance to ride ponies. Cow taming, cattle shoeing and hoof repairing will be present.

datosContacto.direccion: Parking de la estación y alrededores

datosGenerales.nombre: La Arboleda farming and cattle fair
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The popular neighbourhood of La Arboleda holds every year a farming and cattle fair at the beginning of November. This is a very complete market that attracts thousands of people.

 

It should be mentioned the Sheep Cheese Contest, where some of the best regional cheeses will participate. Likewise, those who love good food will find a wide range of products, such as cheese, vegetables and legumes, honey, bread, Basque cake, cider, txakoli wine...

 

As for cattle exhibit, we will find horses, donkeys, goats, cows and birds. Handicrafts fair that includes carvings, engravings and jewellery also on display.

Comic and oriental animation enthusiasts will meet at the new edition of Getxo Comic and Manga Exhibition.

A stage has been arranged for parallel activities: feature films screenings related to comics, workshops, role-playing games, contests, publishing houses presentations, round tables, conferences.

datosContacto.direccion: Plazas Estación de Las Arenas y Santa Eugenia

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In the first full week of December Vitoria-Gasteiz province once again hosts Ardoraba, an event where fine wine takes centre stage.

 Large marquees will be set up in the main squares of Vitoria-Gasteiz for the public to taste wines from the region -Rioja Alavesa and Txakoli from Alava, among others- and elsewhere, accompanied by delicious, imaginative pintxos.

In other words, an unmissable date for lovers of wine and fine food.

Santa Lucia Fair is to be held on December 13th in Zumarraga and Urretxu. This is one of the most important fairs taking place in Gipuzkoa. However, contests and exhibitions start the day before.

 

The Rioja Alavesa Wine Fair kicks off on December 12th in the evening. Iparragirre Square in the town of Urretxu becomes home to about 12 wineries with the intention to show and sell the last harvest wine. Many wine makers enter the 17th Rioja Alavesa Wine Contest, where five oenologists of renown will make up the jury. The fair goes on the following day. Stockbreeders, Basque farmers and the rest of the traders on Santa Lucia day get ready for 8am. An exhibition of horses and other species can be found in Urdaneta Street (Zumarraga), whereas La Salle-Legazpi schoolyard houses different types of farming machinery.

 

As for extraordinary markets, the organisers arrange several stalls in Euskadi Square (Zumarraga), with reineta apples, vegetables, fruit, handicrafts and Basque products such as honey, bread, cheese and talo (Basque food consisting of cornmeal and water). Those who visit Gernikako Arbola Square (Urretxu) will have the chance to purchase fruit, vegetables and Basque products. There, Gipuzkoa's Association of Apiculture will hold the Region's Honey Contest. What's more, Areizaga-Jalebarren (Zumarraga), will house the Hen and Capon Competition.

 

In Iparragirre Street (Urretxu) and Nueva Avenida de Urretxu Avenue and Trintxera building (Zumarraga) and in Euskadi Square, many stands will be distributed with all sorts of handicrafts. Apart from the dozens of exhibitions, musicians will flood the streets of both towns. Txistularis (tabor pipe players), bands and trikitilaris (players of trikitixa, two-row Basque diatonic button accordion) will go over the streets livening up the atmosphere. Ederrena pelota Court, in Urretxu, will prepare an exhibition of rural sports such as pelota contests among professionals and "gizon-proba" (stone dragging by men traction).

Every year Christmas in Vitoria-Gasteiz provide shops, restaurants, services and the visitors with a large amount of plans. Events for all tastes that, together with the streets decoration, lights and the citizens' coming and going, are the special touch that fills the city with a special atmosphere.

Ice skating in La Florida Park

La Florida Park turns into a huge ice rink to delight the audience. From 10:00 to 14:00 and from 16:00 to 20:00.

Huge Crib

What is more, La Florida Park holds a huge crib since 1962 that has become a tradition for those who visit Vitoria on these days. It consists of over 200 dummies of human size as well as buildings, thousands of animals and accessories that will delight those who approach the area from early December to January 6th.

Christmas Playground at the "Centro Civico HEGOALDE" 

A playground full of workshops, barracks and all kinds of entertainment for the little ones.

Christmas markets

The Craft Fair will be held at Independencia street and Celedones de Oro square, whilst the Lan Ta Lan Christmas Fair of Crafts will be set up in the Plaza de la Provincia. The Agricultural Market will take place in Santa Bárbara Square.

Sports

Those who love sports cannot forget two important appointments: Media Maratón and San Silvestre. The first takes place on Dec. 18th. The second goes through the city centre of Vitoria in the evening of December 31st.

Bilbao gets full of lights, colours and music at Christmas. The massive lighting turns the main streets of Bilbao into a huge setting brimming with Christmas carols and all sorts of ornaments. Moreover, shops, bars and restaurants decorate their facilities and shop windows on the occasion. Many of them participate in the traditional Shop Window Contest that has been taking place for the last twenty-four years in Biscay.

 

Cribs

Various points throughout the Biscayan capital house numerous crib exhibitions of all kinds every year. Perhaps the most outstanding exhibition is the one that is in the portico of the church of San Nicolás de Bari, where spectacular audiovisual cribs are on display. As usual, the Diocesan Museum will be holding a worldwide crib exhibition as well as the Holy Week Procession.

 

Santo Tomás Fair 

One of the most celebrated festivities in Bilbao is Santo Tomás. On December 21st thousands of people fill the streets of the old town on the occasion of a day that pays tribute to the farmers and where the best local produce will be ready to be bought.

 

Children's activities 

But then again, it had to be this way. The little ones also enjoy these dates. The Christmas Amusement Park for Children, PIN, will be set up within the Bilbao Exhibition Centre from December 17th to January 8th.

 

San Silvestre

As has been the case in previous years, the Rekalde San Silvestre race will take place on the last day of the year, a race that attracted more than 1,000 runners last year.

As every year, Christmas is felt in all the streets and squares of San Sebastián. The city becomes busy and many activities are arranged to celebrate the special dates.

Santo Tomás Fair 

Rural atmosphere reigns in Santo Tomás Fair, where every year thousands of people meet in Gipuzkoa's capital city. The day programme includes an animal exhibition and several contests. Agricultural produce of top quality will be on display.


Craft fair

The children will enjoy PIN; meanwhile, the adults will have the opportunity to approach the Christmas market in San Sebastián. Urumea Pasealekua and Santa Katalina Square are filled with the culture of the city: tradition, history, handicrafts, food and drink. There is also a tent where a range of activities, workshops and shows take place.

Another option is to approach Urdaneta and Reyes Católicos Streets in order to do their shopping in the Artisan Fair that every year Lur association is responsible for arranging. The collective consists of Artisans from Gipuzkoa who work on leather, paper, glass or wood. Stands will be displaying ceramics, jewellery, toys, soap, runners, clothes, and so on. 

San Silvestre, a massively-attended race

The sportiest citizens await San Silvestre race with illusion, which covers 7,800 metres through the San Sebastián city centre the last day of the year. What is more, San Silvestre means a festive show due to the play atmosphere in which it is developed.

To the rhythm of drumbeats San Sebastián and Azpeitia hold San Sebastián festivity on January 20th, their patron saint's day.

The celebration kicks off on January 19th with music bands livening up the streets' atmosphere in the evening. At 12am in Gipuzkoa's capital Sociedad Gaztelubide society hoists the flag at the Plaza de la Constitución Square. For 24 hours the city becomes a festival full of drums.

The companies parade with their members dressed as chefs and soldiers of ancient times. The melodies of Raimundo Sarriegi sound in every neighbourhood until Unión Artesana association puts an end to the festivity by lowering the flag at 12am.

During the day, the Citizen's Merit Medals will be awarded, along with the Tambor de Oro (Golden Drum). About 8,000 pupils will participate in a different drum parade.

At 10pm about 20 groups of drummers will parade across the streets of Azpeitia in order to end up all together in the town square and play. Apart from Marcha de San Sebastián, drummers will perform pieces by Franzesena. Moreover, about 500 children will make up the tamborrada-txiki on a day that comes to an end with a parade, sokamuturra contest -people running ahead the bull that it is strapped so that the bull can be under control- and many other activities.

As every year, in mid-January, the word Txotx! is shouted out to announce the start of the cider season in the Basque Country. The event makes possible to enjoy the new harvest of natural cider coming straight from barrels (kupelas) till April.

What in its day became a ritual to taste cider wine in order to bottle it up has nowadays turned into a gastronomic feast. Many cider houses open their doors to offer the typical cider house menu consisting of cod omelette, cod with peppers, T-bone steak, cheese with quince and walnuts. All of it accompanied by tasty cider.

According to tradition, every time the responsible for opening the barrels uncovers a new one, he shouts out Txotx!, and guests around the table approach the barrels to taste the cider. People are back and forth continuously.

About 70 cider houses are spread over 24 towns, most of them are located in Astigarraga, Hernani, Usurbil and Urnieta, but other towns of Gipuzkoa, even Bizkaia and Alava, are also home to many of them. Nowadays, families and groups of friends visit cider bars in order to enjoy the tradition and the natural cider.

Mungia and Amurrio will be celebrating San Antón festivity in a very special way. Buying and selling of cattle as well as exhibition, display and sale of machinery and decorative plants and flower designs are part of the programme available on January 17th in Mungia. San Antón festivity is most commonly known as San Antontxu Eguna.

 

Black puddings are important on this day. On the one hand, Mungia celebrates Black Pudding and Chorizo Contest, whereas attendees will have the chance to observe the process of black pudding making. Several Basque pelota games will be taking place in the evening and Trikitilaris (players of trikitixa, a two-row Basque diatonic button accordion) and fanfares will liven up the day.

 

On January 21nd, Amurrio will be holding a massively attended fair. An excellent showcase for farmhouse products, kitchen utensils, preserved food, trees and all sorts of plants. Stands full of a wide range of food such as cheese, bread, honey and tinned food will be at the clients' disposal together with stalls containing jewellery, basketwork, crafts and wool.

 

It is especially outstanding the annual auction that takes place in this town. A wide range of products derived from pork along are put out to tender together with craftworks and agricultural production.

galeria.titulo: Fairs display some of the best regional products

datosGenerales.descripcion:
On December 31st several Basque towns have an appointment with the popular race known as San Silvestre. Festive spirit takes precedence over the competitive character, for which there is also room.

Gipuzkoa

Due to its international level, the most important heat takes place in Beasain. Beti-Bizi association is responsible for managing it and the race covers an area of 9 kilometres. As usual, famous athletes will be participating.  The starting signal is scheduled for 12pm before the train station. Free registration. Only available until 10am.

The mass meeting takes place in Donostia-San Sebastián, though.  The heat, which is organised by Amara Kirol Elkartea association, recorded the participation of 1,500 athletes in the previous edition. This time runners will depart from Benta Berri at 3pm to cover an area of 8.2 kilometres with alterations in its itinerary. This is a traditional race where the winner is not awarded cash prize but a trophy and a voucher for sports equipment.

On San Silvestre day races take place in many other towns such as Azpeitia, Errenteria, Ordizia, Tolosa, Zizurkil and Zarautz.

Bizkaia

Galdakao captures the interest of inhabitants with the  Circuito de Nochevieja Memorial Ramón Gil. The most veteran San Silvestre race of the Spanish State. Club de Atletismo Galdakao conducts the competition. The route is a 1.1 kilometre long urban circuit consisting of 7 categories.

Sodupe and Rekalde (postponed) have also important meetings. Cross de Andra Mari takes place in Getxo at 11am.

Alava

Alava is home to the San Silvestre of Vitoria-Gasteiz. About 1,800 racers are expected to participate. Federation of Athletics of Alava organises what has become one of the most important sports events in the region.

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Errenteria; Donostia / San Sebastián; Ordizia; Zarautz; Bilbao; Galdakao; Getxo; Güeñes; Zizurkil; Beasain; Azpeitia; Vitoria-Gasteiz; Tolosa

datosGenerales.nombre: Presentation of the Getaria Txakoli season
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Every year, on 17th January -coinciding with the feast of San Anton- the new harvest of Getaria Txakoli wines carrying the Designation of Origin seal are presented in Getaria.

The day begins with the celebration of a solemn mass in the church of San Salvador. Then, after formally presenting the harvest of the year at the fronton court in Getaria, attendees can sample more than 1,000 bottles of Txakoli, thanks to about twenty wineries.

There is no shortage of typical local produce from the town, such as the anchovies and tuna, in addition to the delicious pintxos made in the bars and restaurants in Getaria. At midday the prize known as "Mahasti Jauna" (a sculpture made of bronze) will be awarded to people and entities related to the world of Txakoli wine. In the afternoon, there will be displays of a local Basque sport known as herri-kirolak There will be musical entertainment and bertso sessions (impromptu rhyming songs) throughout the whole day.

Year by year San Blas festivity opens February. It falls on February 3rd and several towns scattered over the Basque Country honour tribute to the popular patron saint of throat illnesses. Two fundamental elements cannot be missing: coloured cotton necklaces and sweets dedicated to San Blas. As tradition goes, both of them must be blessed before the saint's statue and the necklace must be worn around the neck for the subsequent 9 days and burnt afterwards so that the saint will protect them against throat illnesses.

Fairs

Apart from the festivity's spiritual sense San Blas preserves a more rural touch in the Basque Country. In fact, many Basque towns celebrate the day with agricultural and cattle fairs dedicated to the patron saint. Laudio will host a festival brimful of activities: display and sale of agricultural produce and artisan products, rural sports, the black pudding making process, dance performances and musical entertainment, a tribute to the local baserritarras (farmers) and there will be chestnut tastings... One of the highlights of the day will be the burning and the scraping of the pig (during the pig slaughter). As part of the festival a Txarripatas (pigs trotters) Gastronomic Competition is also going to be held.

Besides, several towns from Deba region such as Eibar, Soraluze and Elgoibar, among many others, cook delicious San Blas tarts. But without any doubt, San Blas tradition is widely spread in Bizkaia.

Abadiño is witness to hundreds of onlookers and inhabitants who attend the agricultural, cattle and craftwork fairs. Apart from enjoying the cattle, all those who approach Durangaldea region will have the opportunity to buy vegetables, fruit, cheese, txakoli white wine, bread, honey, plants and handicrafts. If this is not enough, the little ones will be delighted with herri kirolak (rural sports), bertso shows (Basque extemporary composed songs) and stone dragging by oxen. 

Other towns in Biscay such as Barrika or the neighbourhood of Axpe, Busturia, also pay tribute to San Blas.

Caldereros fiesta is quite an event in San Sebastián, as well as in other areas of Gipuzkoa, such as Anoeta, Astigarraga, Irun and Tolosa.

Several groups or clubs participate emulating Hungarian gypsies who arrived in the city to sell their products on Carnival day. The Tinkers' Parade is a peculiar way to announce the upcoming Carnival, where tribes of gypsies and beautiful gypsy women delight onlookers and spectators with their marvellous dances.

They will play songs by Raimundo Sarriegui with the oddest instruments such as, frying pans, small saucepans, tinks, hammers and pots. Obviously, the queen and her two ladies (men dressed in women clothes), the bear and the tamer will be the most emblematic characters present at the parade. Music, dance, entertainment, exotic clothing and festive atmosphere are the most outstanding features to describe such a special day. 

Two of the most popular groups are Primitiva Comparsa de Caldereros de la Hungría with over 125 years of history and Caldereros de la Hungría de Gros, created in 1985.

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Anoeta; Irun; Astigarraga; Tolosa; Donostia / San Sebastián

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Oyón will be holding Revolcón del Katxi within the activities programme of San Vicente and San Anastasio festivities.

 

"Katxi" is the name of the most emblematic character of this area of Rioja Alavesa. The exact origin of the fictitious character is unknown but the first references to "Katxi" date back to 1676. Its clothing has undergone changes over the years. Nowadays it is dressed in a felt suit with wide red and green stripes, a hat of the same material and a fox fur coat. "El Cachi" is embroidered on its sleeves and "Viva San Vicente. Oyón-Oion" on its back.

 

The event is scheduled for January 21st and 22nd in front of the parish church and the Town Hall. The celebration is held both days in both places. At the door of the church, Oyón inhabitants stand in a circle near the authorities and several representatives of both the region and clergy, whereas children stand before the door.

 

Once having listened to the first rhythms of la habanera (musical genre from Cuba), Katxi lies on the ground in the middle of the circle and before the culture councillor. The councilman carries the town flag and he flutters it over Katxi, who rolls around under the flag at the rhythm of music. Then, Katxi stands up, launches his hat into the air and all the attendees cheer San Vicente and San Anastasio. Next, they enter the parish church.

 

The unusual scene is repeated before the Town Hall.

galeria.titulo: Revolcón del Katxi (photo: Oyón Town Council)

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Many towns in Bizkaia celebrate the carnival festivities in style. Among different regions, Bilbao, Mundaka, Markina-Xemein and Lekeitio are the most remarkable.

 

On the first day the traditional judgement of 'Farolin' and 'Zarambolas' will take place; the roles of the characters of Farolin and Zarambolas are awarded to popular characters in the community, and they represent the boastfulness and kindness of Bilbao respectively.

 

The krewes will take centre stage in front of the masses that attend the carnivals. The festivities and the atmosphere take over the entire week. The carnival will finish on Tuesday with the burial of the sardine.

 

Not only Bilbao but also the coastal town of Mundaka celebrates in a special way. "Atorras" and "lamias" are the undisputed characters in town. On Sunday, "Atorras" (male inhabitants) go across the streets of the town accompanied by their chants and in the afternoon, "lamias" (female inhabitants) take the baton to keep with the music and good atmosphere.

 

Moreover, the traditional carnivals of Markina-Xemein are also worth mentioning. Young "dantzaris" (Basque dancers) perform "zaragi-dantza" or "danza del odre" down the streets on Sunday, which is one of the most representative dances of the Basque Carnivals. A fearsome bear accompanies the "comparsa" with a tamer that is responsible for keeping ghosts away and frighten children off.

The day prior to Santa Águeda is a celebration of great importance in numerous towns and cities of the Basque geography.

On February 4th, in many towns of Bizkaia, Gipuzkoa and Alava, groups of people and choirs parade down the streets singing canticles to honour Santa Águeda, recalling her life and martyrdom. Rod and walking ("makilas") sticks accompany their canticles.

Among the parades taking place on the occasion of Santa Águeda, we will highlight three processions. The prior Sunday to February 5th, on February 5th and the following Sunday, the inhabitants set course for the Sanctuary of Santa Águeda, which is located in Kastrexana (Barakaldo). The most predominant procession is the one taking place the following Sunday to Santa Águeda Day, as thousands attend the celebration. Santa Águeda was a Sicilian virgin and martyr from the 3rd Century. She is the patron saint of women and fertility that is why so many mother-to-be women turn to her.

She is believed to have great many powers such as the ability to prevent fires and volcano eruptions, protect from bad spirits and cattle diseases and increase cattle production. Among the Basques, Santa Águeda also has the ability to cure cephalalgia and migraines.

Sopuerta holds the Charcuterie Fair on 3th March, one of the most ancient and massively attended fairs in Las Encartaciones region. Within the fair those who attend will find a competition to select the best Basque butcher, another to select the best homemade chorizo (several types of pork sausage) and a morcilla (black pudding) contest.

The stands will display several homemade products available to buy: different type of cheese, baking -Basque cake and bread-, honey, pâté, tinned food, txakoli white wine, cider, and so on. Stalls with crafts will not be missing either basketwork, beads, goatskins- and agricultural machinery. Although, without any doubt, the main feature of the fair is charcuterie. Two typical goods of the region are the most remarkable products: chorizo and morcilla produced in the local style.

datosGenerales.nombre: Passion during Holy Week in Bizkaia
datosGenerales.descripcion: Holy Week is the Christian holidays from Palm Sunday to Resurrection Sunday, although these days also include the previous Friday and Saturday -Holy Friday and Holy Saturday. These days, Bizkaia focuses on Balmaseda and Bilbao, since the celebrations are very spectacular in both cities. Every year masses of visitors meet up in Balmaseda's Way of Sorrows. Different scenes from the life of Jesus performed on Maundy Thursday and Holy Friday attract the tourists. For months, Balmaseda inhabitants have been rehearsaling to show realism during the acts that are accompanied by processions and chants. Twelve processions follow each other for nine days to complete an austere Holy Week. Over three thousand members of religious brotherhoods participate in all the processions. From Holy Friday to Holy Saturday, they accompany "Pasos" or statues of great artistic value. The Penitents' Procession is outstanding. It marches through the neighbourhood of San Francisco, where Flamenco verses (Saetas) are sung and the Silent Procession takes place early morning through the Old Town of Bilbao. Christ's martyrdom is also performed in Bermeo, Orduña, Durango, Berango, Markina-Xemein and Arkotxa neighbourhood in Zaratamo.

datosContacto.direccion: Balmaseda, Berango, Bermeo, Bilbao, Durango, Markina-Xemein, Orduña, Zaratamo

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Markina-Xemein; Urduña/Orduña; Balmaseda; Durango; Bilbao; Zaratamo; Berango; Bermeo

datosGenerales.descripcion:
On 11st April, Laudio/Llodio natives will again make use of the permission granted to them by the church to enjoy farmhouse meats during Easter, in celebration of the Friday of Sorrows, organised by the Aberedunak livestock farmers' association.

 

In addition to the livestock exhibition, which will include cow, horse, sheep, goat and pig livestock from the region of Aiara and from nearby towns Orozko and Orduña, the important bullock stone-dragging competition will also take place.

The popular Palm Fair (Palm Saturday Fair) will be gathering the best selection of local cattle in Bergara. From 9:30am onwards "trikitilaris" (players of trikitixa, a two-row Basque diatonic button accordion) will be in charge of livening up the atmosphere of Avenida Ibargarai area, where the fair will be located.

 

Apart from selling cattle, agricultural and stockbreeding products, the organisers will install several stands containing food labelled Basque quality and artisan brands.

 

In the afternoon in San Martín square the children will have the chance of enjoying games and rural sports. Moreover, at night the "bertsolaris" (Basque verse singers) will celebrate their traditional festival at the pelota court.

galeria.titulo: Products from the vegetable garden available to purchase

datosGenerales.nombre: Fair of San José in Bakio
datosGenerales.descripcion:
As usual, Bakio will be presenting on March 19th in public the txakoli obtained from the previous year's harvest.

 

A popular figure will be responsible for opening the first bottle with designation of origin Bizkaiko Txakolina. Apart from the prized white wine, those who approach the coastal town will have the chance of tasting some of the best local products such as cheese, bread, lamb and Basque cake.

 

Available on stalls will be handicrafts and basketwork. And sheep, goats, pottoks, dogs and many more animals also make up the fair, among more animals. On the other hand, sports activities are one of the major attractions.

 

Bat game, the Grand Prize San José Stone dragging by oxen, and rural sports (herri kirolak) exhibitions will liven up the day of those who approach eager to taste the delicious txakoli from Bakio.

galeria.titulo: Txakoli, one of the main attractions

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Berdel Eguna or Mackerel Day is beyond all doubt one of the most popular and more crowded events of Mutriku. The initiative was launched more than ten years ago by the San Pedro Fishermen's Guild and aims to promote and to spread the quality of the mackerel.

Although several activities will be organised on the days leading up to the festivity, such as the presentation of the "Berdel aipamena" award, or photography exhibitions, the main Mackerel Day celebrations will be held on April 6th. People attending the celebration will have the opportunity to taste this fish cooked in a dozen of different recipes. In fact, thousands of pintxos will be served in the famous port of the village, with a common ingredient: mackerel.

The local catering establishments will also distribute tapas made with mackerel.

A large number of people participate every year in one of the most important sports events of Bizkaia's capital: Bilbao-Bilbao Cycling March.

 

The race departs from Deusto Bridge, near Zubiarte Shopping Centre and finishes on Gran Vía Street. One start will take place every 15 minutes. Five starts are scheduled in all. No sort of qualifying will take place when the race ends as the contest lies in everyone riding at his or her speed.

 

3 cycle routes (85, 115 and 125 kilometres) will be offered. Participants will travel through numerous Biscayan towns such as Getxo, Plentzia, Sondika, Larrabetzu and Galdakao, amongst others. As has been the case in previous years, the fluid/food station area will be located in Zamudio Technology Park, a place where the cyclists will have access to food and beverages.

Shepherds' Day in Ordizia focuses on pastoral practices, shepherds and cheese. Exhibition and display of rams, lamb tasting and the new Idiazabal Cheese campaign are the most remarkable events included in the programme.

 

During the morning, more than 200 sheep will run through the streets of the Old Quarter in Ordizia, commemorating the flocks of sheep passing through the villages. Shepherds' Day is also the chosen day to hold the contest/exhibition of the Latxa breed of sheep, one of the most important in the Basque Autonomous Community, both for their quality, as well as for the number of sheep on show.

 

Other activities to take place during the days events will be the art of sheep shearing exhibition (manually and mechanically) and a demonstration showing how cheese is made, especially devoted for the kids. There will also be a fair where typical cheese and produce from Goierri and the rest of Gipuzkoa will be on sale.

 

Music by the local trikitilaris and dulzaineros will provide entertainment and liven up the day. Throughout the day, apart from events that will make us be more familiar with the pastoral practices, it is worth mentioning that the official presentation of Idiazabal Cheese is bound to take place. Every year, a celebrity related to the product is responsible for presenting the occasion.

galeria.titulo: Flocks down the streets of Ordizia

datosGenerales.descripcion:
It will come as no surprise that honey is the central theme of all activities programmed for Beekeepers' Day.

Although numerous activities related to honey, apiculture and bees will be organised on the days leading up to the event, it's on 3th April when the main Beekeepers' Day celebrations will get underway.

During the morning, the Honey Contest of Gipuzkoa will be held, in which only the winners of the regional contests can enter. There will also be an exhibition of pastries and desserts, cakes and sweets made by top Basque pastry chefs. As in previous years, a tribute will be paid to both the most prominent beekeepers of the year and to the bees, the true stars of the event. Additionally, the community tasting of sweets and honey and the local community lunch will delight lovers of good food.

galeria.titulo: Bees are the protagonists of the fair

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Itzulia Basque Country-Vuelta al País Vasco 2024 is once again to turn Basque roads into the setting for six intense days packed with excitement, from 1st to 6th April. In this edition of the cycle tour of the Basque Country the cyclists will cover 992,5 kilometres in a total of six stages, one of them in the form of an individual time trial. The route includes climbing 26 mountain passes: three category 1, seven category 2 and sixteen category 3.

The cycle tour of the Basque Country will begin in Irun and end in Eibar.

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Eibar; Vitoria-Gasteiz; Hondarribia; Amurrio; Laudio/Llodio; Zamudio; Mallabia

galeria.titulo: Cycling Tour in the Basque Country
Cycling Tour in the Basque Country
Cycling Tour in the Basque Country

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Sagardo Eguna brings together about 40 cider houses from the whole Euskadi, mainly from Gipuzkoa. They will place their stands in Alameda de Gamón, Lehendakari Agirre and Foru Plaza Square. For a reasonable price the visitor will get one "pintxo" and a glass to fill it with all the cider he or she wants, as well as the typical neckerchief as a present.

Pintxos with Eusko Label calf meet are worth a special mention. However, the event is officially presented at 6pm with "txalapartaris" and "irrintzilaris" calling out to the attendees for the cider tasting. Next, cider will be poured out.

datosContacto.direccion: Alameda de Gamón, Plaza Lehendakari Agirre, Foru Plaza

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Plants from the five continents will give extraordinary colour to the Iturraran Botanical Garden, at the Parque Natural de Pagoeta (Aia), during the ninth Collectors Plant Fair that will be held on 29th and 30th April.

 

A total of forty-seven horticulturists will present their collections so visitors can admire or acquire plants that are little-known in these latitudes, but easy to grow in gardens or balconies. So, attendees can come across cactus, aromatic and edible plants, bonsai, peonies, carnivorous plants, camellias, mimosas, bamboos and ornamental shrubs from Australia and New Zealand and many more. Those who approach the event will have a nice day as they will have the opportunity to taste some of the most typical products of the region talo, cider, Idiazabal cheese, cheeses with ancient recipes, pintxos- as well as visiting paths of the Botanical Garden, which is an interesting place for lovers of plants. Moreover, a children's playground will be fitted out in the place for the little ones.

datosContacto.direccion: Jardín Botánico de Iturraran. Parque Natural de Pagoeta

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Bilbao BBK Live Festival 2024 has revealed its most contemporary lineup, including Arcade Fire, Massive Attack and The Prodigy. 

Bilbao BBK Live Festival expands on its lineup with an array of new acts confirmed for Basoa ["The Forest"], the festival’s carefully curated electronic music space. With its unique setting, well-selected line-up and precisely configured sound system, the forest is a temple of escapism, where you can forget about your mobile phone and immerse yourself in the moment.

Expovacaciones will take us on a tour of the best travel destinations around the world and will have a wide range of travel options on offer to the public who make their way to Bilbao Exhibition Centre (BEC).

At Expovacaciones 2024 raffles, exhibitions, tastings and activities related to promoting the tourism industry will also be held.

A complete luxury for the most demanding palates is, in a few word, the perfect description of the sweet fair Tolosa Goxua. Cake shops in Tolosa (Gorrotxategi, Casa Eceiza, Gorosti, Gozona and Saizar) play the leading role on this day by presenting their latest creations. The Plaza del Triángulo Square will hold several stalls where the local confectioners will be selling the traditional Tolosa confections. Cake sellers and confectioners from Gipuzkoa, Álava, Biscay, the North Basque Country and La Rioja will also have their sweets on display.

 

In this "goxua" fair, the protagonists will be the positions of the confectioners and local pastry chefs: -Gorrotxategi, Eceiza, Gorosti, Ibañez-Gozona y Saizar and together with other who will come from outside and we will have the opportunity to taste the most sweet products of Tolosa and discover firsthand the most interesting novelties of the confectionery and current confectionery.

Since 1998 this fair has been taking place in the town of Idiazabal where the young cheeses of the season are presented to the public. Although several events will be organized in the days leading up to the fair, the official day devoted to such a prized delicacy is on the first Sunday in May.

Early in the morning the shepherds stalls will be open to the public. All those in attendance can sample the cheese and vote for their favourite. Last year close to 500 kilos were distributed. Additionally, the fair will feature other produce such as honey, chocolate, txakoli, cider, wine, bread and much more.

Two local shepherds show how cheese is made, each in their own way: one of them makes the cheese using traditional methods, while the other uses more modern techniques. Shortly after, visitors can see in situ the process of smoking cheese as well as the preparation of the curd. During the morning visitors can see a shepherd leading his sheep.

Otxomaios is a traditional fiesta celebrated in our lands. As the name points out Ocho, eight in Spanish; Mayo means May- on May 8th the inhabitants celebrate the apparition of Orduña's patron saint; La Virgen de La Antigua.

Local authorities parade towards the Sanctuary of La Antigua to pay tribute to the Virgin together with macebearers and clarinettists. The previous night the "txupinazo" is the official starting signal for Otxomaios.

Activities run until mid May. Sports activities, several contests, cattle fairs, dance and theatre shows, concerts, open-air dances, bullfights, street music bands, popular meals and many events for the little ones are just a few of the programme activities planned to enjoy Otxomaios.

Fantasy films are about to take over Bilbao, the capital of the Biscay region.

 

Once again, the best international cinema in the genre will combine with a wide range of interesting activities (music sessions, workshops, etc.), which are sure to delight anyone who loves fantasy films.

Amurrio celebrates Txakoli Day (Día del Txakoli/Txakolinaren Eguna),  on the occasion of the presentation of the 2023 txakoli harvest.

Those who attend the event will have the chance of tasting the wine labelled Arabako Txakolina designation of origin.

In addition, fair organisers pay tribute annually to an important figure that somehow, has promoted the txakoli wine.

Atoñana, in Campezo, plays host to the 27th Spring Fair of Montaña Alavesa. Among the events included in the programme arranged by the Administrative Board of Antoñana stands out the Honey Contest.

 

 

 

 

 

We cannot forget that the honey produced in this region of Alava has been awarded Eusko Label Certificate of Quality. Artisan products on sale or to taste will also be at the onlookers' disposal.

Vitoria-Gasteiz hosts the marathon dedicated to the athlete Martín Fiz.

Participants, who must be at least 18 years old, will have to complete a route of around 42 kilometres, which will run through the city centre and the outskirts of the city.

In addition, the marathon offers other races of different distances: 21 kilometres, 10 kilometres and the children's distance.

The San Sebastian Half Marathon is one of the year's most attractive events for lovers of athletics. The route is just over 21 kilometres long and the participants must complete two laps of a flat circuit which begins and finishes in the Boulevard in San Sebastian and passes through some of the city's most emblematic spots such as the Paseo de La Concha and the Avenida de La Zurriola.

 

There is also the option of taking part in the 10 Kilometre Race, in which participants must only complete one lap of the circuit. Over the years the San Sebastian Half Marathon has become a hugely important race on the international stage; thousands of athletes take part every year, many of whom come from other countries.

Several towns in mid May celebrate San Isidro festivities, which pay tribute to the patron saint of farmers.

The activities' programme is very similar in most of towns: street bands, music to dance to, open-air dances, gastronomy contests, popular meals, sports events Basque pelota tournaments, rural sports exhibitions-, processions, and so on. In most cases, the festivities come together with livestock shows, agricultural fairs and handicrafts.

 

In Alava, for instance, the agricultural fair, livestock show and handicrafts are the most remarkable events of Respaldiza (Ayala). San Isidro festivities have been celebrated on May 15th in this region for more than thirty years. The livestock fair, cheese contest, roast beef tasting, and sale and showing of agricultural machinery and artisan products of high quality are just a few of the fair attractions. Other Alava towns paying tribute to the patron saint are Laguardia, Lapuebla de Labarca, Campezo, Zigoitia and Bitoriano (Zuia), among others.

 

As for Bizkaia, the towns of Derio, Basauri (Benta neighbourhood), Getxo, Larrabetzu, Orduña, Leioa, Abadiño, Barakaldo (Cruces neighbourhood), Balmaseda and many areas of Busturialdea, celebrate the festivities in honour of San Isidro. The most outstanding fairs take place in Larrabetzu ¿agricultural fair with free tastings- and Zeanuri ¿stalls with handicrafts and agricultural objects, as well as a livestock fair.

 

To conclude, Gipuzkoa also celebrates San Isidro. Ataun, for instance, holds a traditional market with the best locally grown products ¿such as cheeses and cider- at the visitors' disposal. Sheep shearing is also possible to observe, as well as participating in the vegetable contest. As for Astigarraga and Antzuola, both regions hold agricultural fairs and livestock shows. But in Antzuola the scarecrow contest is an extraordinary experience. On the other hand, Villabona, Getaria, Azpeitia, Oiartzun, Arrasate/Mondragón, Hernani, Mutriku and Anoeta, will carry out many activities, among many other towns.

About thirty exhibitors will come together in Lamera Park to showcase their produce, some of which is difficult to source in the everyday fish markets. So, visitors will be able to purchase different varieties of smoked, frozen, preserved and pre-cooked fish and seafood.

Every year, the fair focuses on one particular theme and the Hegaluze prize is awarded to people, groups or companies that have worked or contributed to Bermeo in some way to spread the name of the town. There will be a wide range of activities.

Additionally, as has been the case in previous years, a pintxos contest will be organized as part of the Arrain Azoka fair.

On 18th May museums from all around the world will celebrate the International Museum Day with several special activities.

Obviously, Basque museums will also celebrate this important day with a wide range of activities.

One of the most attractive aspects of the International Museum Day is that the entrance to most of the museums will be free or that they will offer great discounts.

For one day, the coastal town of Ondarroa centres on the anchovy; its most emblematic fish. "Antxoa Egune" (Anchovy Day) offers a programme consisting of activities related somehow to the world of anchovies.

 

 

The main festivity day is scheduled for Saturday. Highlights of the programme are the sale of regional canned goods and products, exhibitions (old photos, models) or musical and theatre performances.

 

Also, over 1,000 pintxos will be given out, with anchovies as the main ingredient.

Bioterra- the European Fair of Biological Products- is staging a new edition at FICOBA. The fair is split into three large areas: Bioterra, which focuses on the earth's ecological products; Geobat, where bio-construction and renewable energies are explored; and Naturall, dedicated to cosmetics, hygiene, and natural remedies. There will be more than one hundred stands, as well as free courses, kitchen demonstrations in situ, exhibitions, games and workshops for kids, raffles...

 

The entrance will be free and you can get it online: Tickets.

The town of Baranbio, in Amurrio, is responsible for holding the 23th Ahuntz Eguna or Día de la Cabra (Goat Day). The surroundings of the hermitage of Garrastatxu, in Baranbio (Amurrio) will be home to the shepherds from the region, where they will meet up.

 

When the activities' programme highlights a contest of Azpigorri and Azpizuri goats, the most common species in the area- and a livestock show of goats. As in previous editions, a stone-dragging contest by goats will not miss this year's appointment .

 



Those who come over to the town from Alava will be allowed to take part in tastings consisting in recipes containing goat cheese during the massively attended popular meal or during the procession.

datosContacto.direccion: Alrededores de la ermita de Garrastatxu. Baranbio

datosGenerales.descripcion:
From June to October, every first Saturday of the month, Gernika-Lumo arranges a special market. Every fair centres on different local produce. Producers from Busturialdea region and guest producers with specific local goods of quality are chosen for every Saturday.

The mentioned fairs will start on June 1st. The first market will focus on Txakoli wine from the Urdaibai region. This way, onlookers will have the chance to buy and taste txakoli white wine with the Designation of Origin of Bizkaiko Txakolina provided by several local txakolindegis (txakoli houses). Besides, baserritarras (Basque farmers) will bring fruit and vegetables of high quality to the market. Clearly, more produce will be at the visitors disposal as follows: cheese -Idiazabal, goat and cow cheese-, honey, pate, bread, Basque cake and chocolate, as well as stalls displaying handicrafts and exhibitions of rural sports.

And the little ones will have a space specially for themselves with bouncy castles, games and activities.

Every year, thousands of people participate in the procession of the Sanctuary of Urkiola (Abadiño) on June 13th.

 

The tradition goes that on San Antonio de Padua Day, those who attend the festivity must complete seven laps around a rock known as "tximistarri", which is located before the sanctuary dedicated to San Antonio de Padua. In return, the rock, which is the defender of issues and lost causes, will help find or keep the couple relationship or whatever the pilgrim asks.

 

Festive atmosphere spreads out over the day. Trikitilaris -players of trikitixa, a two-row Basque diatonic button accordion- and bertsolaris -singers of bertsos, extemporary composed songs in Basque- will make the day more enjoyable.

 

Moreover, as usual in these sorts of events, the streets will have numerous stalls with farming and stockbreeding products, as well as handicrafts and a wide selection of our lands' best products at the clients' disposal.

Several masses will be held too.

galeria.titulo: Those who attend complete seven laps around the rock

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Street art is about to claim Vitoria-Gasteiz for a few days.

Dance, magic, theatre, music, comedy, clown shows, mime artists and games are the staples of the Kaldearte Festival, now in its 18th edition.

Kosta Trail is a sportive event in due form.

Anyone can participate as there are three different kinds of races in terms of difficulty. In other words, it offers professional athletes, families and groups of friends willing to do some sport, the opportunity to enjoy the beauty of the spectacular coastal landscape of Biscay.

The Mountain Race (21 kilometres), which starts and finishes in the town of Sopela. The entire route runs along the cliffs of the Biscayan coast.

The Family Walk (7 kilometres) is perfect to enjoy beautiful views with your family or with your friends, while the Mountain Walk (20 kilometres) will ravish trekking and mountain lovers.

When Saint John comes, different areas of the Basque Autonomous Region celebrate the patron saint's day, neighbourhood festivities, rituals and obviously, numerous bonfires. In fact, groups of youngsters or adults erect one tree with no branches in several town squares ("the tree of St. John"). Subsequently, they set fire to the log. The night from 23rd to 24th of June is popularly known as the shortest of the year June 21st in the shortest anyway- and the arrival of summer solstice is celebrated.

In fact, Gipuzkoa holds important celebrations in towns such as Tolosa, Eibar, Arrasate-Mondragón, Hernani and Andoain, among many other areas. Tolosa arranges a broad programme with different activities, such as the celebrated parade where bordontzaris (blacksmiths), txistularis (Basque flute players), escopeteros (gunsmiths) and members of the music band march down the streets. On the other hand, Eibar offers concerts, dancing shows, sports competitions, musical ensembles, children's workshops, and so on.

As for Alava, we should highlight the traditional celebration held in Laguardia, where the figure of the "cachimorro" leads the parade ahead of a group of dancers. He stands out in the crowd since he wears colourful clothes and he walks towards the town square together with the mayor and the youngest councillor of town. There, the flag of Laguardia is lowered onto the street and later taken to the church of San Juan in order to be offered to the Virgin of El Pilar by means of tremolación de la bandera, which is a traditional ceremony. Likewise, Salvatierra-Agurain and Amurrio also hold St. John festivity.

Many are the towns in Bizkaia that celebrate St. John in a special way. Leioa -with massively attended bonfires before the Town Hall, the ritual meeting of witches known as Akelarre in the area of mobile bars, aka txosnas, and many concerts -, Muskiz -open-air dances, contests, concerts, family activities, and so on-, Getxo, Bermeo, Sopelana and Amallo neighbourhood, Markina-Xemein. As for the capital of Bizkaia, Bilbao's massively attended bonfire takes place in Artxanda.

galeria.titulo: St. John is a magical night

datosGenerales.descripcion:
On the last Sunday of June, Ondategi (Zigoitia), a village in Alava, will celebrate The Gorbeia Foothill Horse Exhibition, which is one of the most popular events in the region.

In the morning, a horse, cattle, ship and goat exhibition will take place. After the exhibition there will be several activities such as a horse jumping competition, a horseball competition and harness racing.

 

As in previous years, a typical Basque woodchopping championship will be held with the participation of the best aizkolaris (wood-shoppers) of the moment. Furthermore, artisans will make their creations available to the public and the whole family will get a lot of entertainment with bouncy castles. Basque dances and brass bands will liven up the day.

Every June 30th on San Marcial Day, gunpowder smell fills Irun streets. This is the day in which several companies march through the city with rifles. The celebration commemorates the day when Irun troops defeated French and German troops on June 30th, 1522.

The parade recalls that night. The sound of fifes and drums combine with the thunder of thousands of rifles firing at the same time following the general's order. Several companies make up the "alarde" military review. Each of them wears special uniforms -white shirt, trousers, red beret and belt-, which varies depending on the group the member belongs to: infantry, soldierts, drummers, artillery, calvary, axemen, and so on.

They march towards San Marcial Mountain, where a huge religious celebration will be taking place to honour the Saint. Two different parades have been held from over ten years on. The first "alarde", known as the "traditional" one, takes place first. Around 8,000 people make it up, where women are allowed to participate just as "cantineras". The following is a "mixed alarde", where around 2,000 men and women take part. Women participate as "cantineras", gunwomen, make up troops playing "txilibito" (whistle) and the drum roll.

datosGenerales.nombre: Eusko Label League of Racing Rowboats
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Basque waters will be again witness of an amazing sport event. The Liga Eusko Label, a traditional traineras competition, begins in July. And for three months, several towns will witness about 20 competitions.

The current 12 best rowing teams take part every year in this thrilling competition. The traineras qualifying for the Eusko Label  league this year are:
Santurtzi, Hondarribia, Orio, Donostiarra, Zierbena, Bermeo, Ondarroa, Cabo, Samertolameu Fandicosta, Lekittarra, Getaria and Kaiku
.

The event on the water is guaranteed to be spectacular, as are the celebrations on land.

localizacion.nombreMunicipio: Hondarribia; Portugalete; Getxo; Orio; Pasaia; Donostia / San Sebastián; Zarautz; Zumaia; Bermeo; Bilbao
localizacion.nombreLocalidad: Orio; Pasai San Pedro; Pasai Donibane; Donostia / San Sebastián; Zarautz; Zumaia

datosGenerales.descripcion:
From June to October Gernika-Lumo town celebrates on the first Saturday of the month a thematic fair based on a specific produce. Bizkaia's town commemorates its Gernika Green Pepper Day, in which this priceless produce, awarded with the Eusko Label quality label more than a decade ago, becomes the main protagonist.

 

Visitors will have the chance to taste pintxos elaborated with this variety of pepper while they try some txakoli wine from Bizkaia or wine from La Rioja Alavesa. A total satisfaction for gourmets. Furthermore, and like every Saturday, baserritarras (farmers) and peasants from the region put at visitors' disposal all sorts of fruits and vegetables at the Plaza del Mercado Square.

 

Artisans have also a place in the fair, where we can find pieces of basketwork or ceramics, among others. Besides, workshops and games have been planned for the children.
Colour blue nankeen and festive atmosphere fill the Old Town of Ondarroa to celebrate a popular fiesta: "Zapato Azule" meaning, "blue Saturday".

galeria.titulo: Poster of popular fiesta Zapato Azule

datosGenerales.nombre: Festivities of San Pedro in Lekeitio
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Kaxarranka, Kilin-Kala and Aurresku de Mujeres are traditional Basque dances well-known among the Basques.

San Pedro's festivity is the most important day in June. It is celebrated on the 29th and starts with the High Mass followed by San Pedro's procession, which leaves from the church of Santa María and walks down the streets up to the harbour. It is here where an unusual ceremony known as Kilin-Kala is held.

The procession members bear a statue of the Saint that will be bent over the water. The ritual is thought to be favourable for fishing. The local street band accompanies the bearers. Next, "dantzaris" (typical Basque dancers) perform the celebrated Kaxarranka. A man dances on a large chest or "kutxa" carried on eight fishermen's shoulders. The performance involves three parts: a "Zortziko", a "Fandango" and an "Arin-Arin". The dancing takes place first in the port, under the image of San Pedro. 

Then, people walk down the streets of the town passing by the house of the current fishermen guild president, the main square and the Town Hall accompanied by the sound of the "txistu" (Basque flute), the tabor and the kettledrum. At noon, classic Aurresku de Mujeres (women's aurresku) takes place in the town's main square. In the evening, the popular "tamborrada" (drums parade) marches down the streets. Next day is the turn of "San Pedro Txiki". Music performances are to be found aplenty. The local street band will offer a show under the image of San Pedro followed by an open-air dance at night in Tala, near the breakwater. 

At 11pm the local street band will set out on a short trip from Tala to the Town Hall stairs. On July 1st an open-air dance is scheduled to take place between Tortola and Beheko Kale Streets before the image of the Saint.

The primary aim of dFeria, the San Sebastián Theatre Festival, is to put new energy into the performing arts market by promoting in particular the Basque companies.

 

Each year nearly 30 performances are scheduled.

galeria.titulo: dFeria, Performing Arts Fair in San Sebastian

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Antzuola town, in Gipuzkoa, holds every year the traditional Moors' Parade. The procession celebrates the battle against Abd al-Rahman III at Valdejunquera on July 26, 920, in which a company made up of Antzuola neighbours defeated him.

 

The arms parade goes along the streets of the town and finishes in the square, where a small performance is carried out. The mayor reads a passage that describes what occurred in Valdejunquera. Nowadays the discourse is a little bit changed but compiles most part of the blazon discourse of 1745. It will be that moment when "bertsos" (Basque poems) by José María Iparraguirre, from Urretxu, will be heard.

 

The flute and drum sound throughout the whole parade, which play "Marcha de Fusileros para Pífanos y Tambores de Espinos. Música de Ordenanza de Carlos III", dating back to 1761. The town banner will be on show, which is made of different drawings similar to the town's barracks that can also be found in the blazon of 1745.

 

The parade takes place within the patron saint festivals of Antzuola, on the third weekend of July, Saturday.

One more year, the long-awaited event for many, Vitoria-Gasteiz Jazz Festival, arrives with a programme that includes artists such as Gregory Porter, Regina Carter, Danilo Pérez, Avishai Cohen, Larry Grenadier, Chris Potter, Jonathan Blake, Marco Mezquida or the legendary gospel singers Golden Gate Quartet, among others.

Throughout a week in July, jazz music becomes the protagonist of the city, becoming one of the essential elements of the summer. Jazz on the Street, midnight jazz, jazz at the official venues… an excellent group of artists will make the local and foreign population enjoy the best jazz music at one of the best festivals of its genre in Europe.

The Jazzaldia is back. From 23 to 28 July, San Sebastian will become the epicentre of jazz music with established and emerging artists such as Rufus Wainwright, Diana Krall, Marisa Monte, Sílvia Pérez Cruz and Gregory Porter, among others. In addition, on the Keler Gunea stage you can enjoy free concerts by Izaro on the 24th and Chill Mafia on the 27th.

The Donostia Jazzaldia is the oldest festival in Spain and one of the longest-running in Europe. All the big names in jazz, without exception, have passed through San Sebastian. Check out the programme to make sure you don't miss a single concert.

As every summer, in mid July the Basque towns of Santurtzi and Barakaldo celebrate their popular fiestas to pay tribute to their patron saint, the Virgin of Carmen. During these days many and diverse activities and events are organised, although each town has its particular approach to the celebration.

 

In Santurtzi this festivity has much to do with the town's fishing tradition. During these fiestas people dress an arrantzales' (fishermen) traditional costume consisting of navy-blue skirt and white petticoats with green, white and red ribbons (the colours of the Basque flag) for women; and navy-blue trousers for men. Both wear also white shirts or, failing that, a T-shirt with their cuadrilla's logo or motto. On the day of the Virgin, July 16th, it is a tradition to make a pilgrimage from the church of San Jorge to the port, carrying an image of the Virgin. Once the procession reaches the harbour, the celebration ends with a flower offering to the sea in honour of those who deceased in the sea. At the end of the day a popular sardine tasting is organised.

 

Besides, both in Barakaldo and Santurtzi, their respective mascots, Jolín for Barakaldo and Mentxu, the seagull for Santurtzi, as well as the cuadrillas play an important role during the fiestas.

 

In Amorebieta the festivities begin the day before the feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel (15th July) and go on until 27th, Santanatxu day. Highlights among the many activities organised include the Tamborrada drumming (for both adults and children) and the parade of Cuadrilla groups. Santanatxu day has a particularly local flavour which is highly popular with the people of Amorebieta.

 

What is more, many towns in Bizkaia such as Balmaseda, Bakio, Bermeo, Neguri, Lemoiz, Plentzia, Larrabasterra, Zalla (El Carmen neighbourhood) and Mungia (Butroi neighbourhood) will be paying tribute to the Virgen del Carmen through several activities.

datosGenerales.nombre: Kaleka, Lekeitio International Street Art Festival
datosGenerales.descripcion:
For more than 20 years now, Lekeitio has been hosting the largest street theatre festival in the Basque Country, and one of the leading events in terms of European street theatre.

In the unique setting on the streets of Lekeitio, with the sea as a backdrop, several companies will perform their latest creations for the public.

The Gipuzkoan town of Orio will play host to the "Orio style" Sea Bream Festival, which aims to be a great showcase for the town and its restaurants. In July, Herriko Plaza in Orio will be turned into a "giant grill".

They will grill more than 500 sea bream "Orio style", that is to say, without using a fish grill. Approximately 1,000 people will enjoy the fiesta.

datosGenerales.nombre: Day of the Blouse and the Neska
datosGenerales.descripcion:
As a warm-up of the Virgen Blanca festivities on July 25th, Santiago Day, Vitoria-Gasteiz celebrates Day of the Blouse and the Neska. About 25 mixed "cuadrillas" -groups of boys and girls; boys' cuadrillas are known as "blusas" and girls' "neskas"- dress a dark smock ("blusa"), espadrilles and a neckerchief.

The story goes that in past times, "cuadrillas" used to meet to attend the bullring wearing the typical work smocks not to get dirty. Later, the clothing changed to start wearing the traditional Basque clothing. "Blusas" and "neskas" attend the cemetery in order to pay a floral tribute to de deceased "blusas" from Vitoria.

One of the highest points of the festival is when about 25 "cuadrillas" parade ("paseíllo") through the streets of Alava's capital -also during Virgen Blanca festivities- to the bullring.

A "blusa" is responsible for conducting the Municipal Band in Parque de la Florida Park.

galeria.titulo: Day of the Blouse and the Neska

datosGenerales.descripcion:
